questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is a complete sulcus?
questions.explanation:
The collateral sulcus is a complete sulcus. A complete sulcus is one that is deep enough to indent 
the wall of a ventricle. The posterior part of the calcarine sulcus is an axial sulcus and the anterior part is a complete 
sulcus. Therefore, among the options provided, the collateral sulcus is the best answer.

questions.explanation:
The anterior part of the calcarine sulcus is considered a complete sulcus because its depth creates 
an elevation in the medial wall of the occipital horn of the lateral ventricle. This is called the calcar 
avis. However, the posterior part of the calcarine sulcus is considered an axial sulcus as its axis is along 
the visual cortex. 364

questions.question: Question 3: Where is Heschl's gyrus located?
questions.explanation: Heschl's gyrus is located in the primary auditory cortex (area 41, 42).

options.a: Area marked A is Broca's area (44, 45) and is present in the inferior frontal gyrus
options.b: Area marked B is the visual association Area (17, 18) and is present around the calcarine sulcus
options.c: Area marked C is the motor association area (5, 6) and is found in the superior parietal lobule
options.d: Area marked D is the frontal eye field (8) and is found in the middle frontal gyrus

questions.explanation:
Area marked D is the frontal eye field (8) and is located in the posterior part of the middle frontal 
gyrus. It controls the conjugate movements of the eyes. It is connected to the visual part of 
the occipital cortex. Lesions here cause loss of horizontal conjugate movements. 365

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient presents to you with inability to form words but can make noises. He also knows 
what he wants to say. What area of the brain has been damaged in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Broca's aphasia in which the Broca's area will be 
affected. In Broca's aphasia/ Motor aphasia / Non-fluent aphasia, areas 44 and 45 in the prefrontal and 
premotor facial regions of the cerebral cortex are affected. The affected individuals will 
have difficulty forming verbal or written words. The comprehension aspect of speech 
is preserved but the person cannot repeat or name the words and lacks fluency. Patients in whom the area is severely affected may have very few words to express all of their 
emotions.

questions.question:
Question 6: In individuals with a history of substance abuse and addiction, the marked structure is 
believed to trigger cravings on exposure to environmental cues. Which of the following is not 
true about the structure? 362 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: It forms the base of the sylvian cistern
options.c: It lies between the frontal and temporal lobe
options.d: It receives somatosensory inputs from the entire body

questions.explanation:
The structure marked by the arrow is the insular lobe. The insular cortex is not entirely 
agranular. The posterior part of the insular cortex is granular and the anterior part is agranular. The insula forms the base of the Sylvian cistern and lies between the frontal and temporal lobes. It 
receives somatosensory, viscerosensory, homeostatic, and nociceptive information from the entire 
body. It receives inputs from the thalamus. 366 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A 72-year-old man presents with a speech abnormality following a hemorrhagic stroke. He 
does not understand any written words or conversation. His speech is fluent but is 
incomprehensible. Repetition is also impaired. Where is the lesion located?
questions.explanation:
In the clinical scenario, comprehension and repetition are impaired while the fluency is 
intact. This points to Wernicke’s aphasia. The area affected is Wernicke's area located in 
the superior temporal gyrus (marked 4). Broca’s motor speech area (44,45) is located in the inferior frontal gyrus. 367 
Sold by @itachibot White Matter of the Brain
